metadata.sermon_title: Disciplines Shared in Gratitude Second Sunday of Advent, Year C
metadata.sermon_start_end: I can imagine Tom Rice, twenty years from now, writing a letter of farewell as he retires from Worthington Presbyterian Church. That letter will be like the one that Paul wrote to the church in Philippi [...] I have no doubt that as the Jesus movement practices these disciplines, the entire power structure of Tiberius, Pilate, and Herod tremble, because they know down deep that this is the good wave of the future.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific Bible passage. It treats Philippians 1, Luke 3, and 1 Corinthians 13 as a thematic collage. Instead of finding what is unique to the Philippians text, it uses it as a springboard for a topical speech on 'discipleship' and 'gratitude'.
quotes: Paul’s letter might be a model for Tom’s letter...
The Gospel reading for today situates John the Baptist...
But like almost every wedding these days, part of 1 Corinthians 13 was read.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope (e.g., Philippians 1:3-11) and isolate what this text says that cannot be found elsewhere, rather than merging it with other famous passages.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic awareness of the political context in Luke 3, but the exegesis of the primary text (Philippians) is superficial. The preacher identifies the names but does not delve into the specific theological weight of the Greek concepts beyond general definitions.
quotes: Luke knows the big players. He names the emperor, Tiberius; he names the governor.
The phrase means to many folk a focus on sexuality... But in fact it means not to be entrapped in the habits of fear...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond naming historical figures to explain the specific theological tension within the Greek text of Philippians regarding the 'koinonia' (partnership) mentioned in verse 5.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the local church situation (the installation of a minister), but it often lapses into general social-political commentary that borders on 'general truths' which Dekker forbids.
quotes: Tom’s mandate in his new assignment is as minister of discipleship.
a harvest of poor people with adequate housing, a harvest of disabled people with full access...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid listing general social justice goals; instead, apply the specific 'overflowing love' of the text to the concrete spiritual 'misery' of the specific congregation.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured in blocks (I, II, III, IV). While it attempts to bridge the text and the present, the movement is often from a contemporary anecdote (the wedding, the retirement) back to the text, rather than the text 'expounding' the hearer.
quotes: I can imagine Tom Rice, twenty years from now...
Tia and I went to a family wedding recently.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the biblical text to be the active subject that analyzes the present, rather than using contemporary anecdotes to illustrate the text.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon focuses heavily on 'gratitude' and 'discipleship' (works), but the 'misery' (sin/incapacity) is framed primarily as social/political 'greed' and 'fear' rather than man's misery before God. Redemption is presented more as a 'transformative work' we do than a gift from outside.
quotes: Thankfulness is the primary mark of the Christian life.
habits of fear, anxiety, greed, selfishness, and violence that render us unqualified...
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by addressing the spiritual inability of the hearer to love, rather than just blaming the 'dominant society'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are present in the contrast between the 'empire' and the 'Jesus movement'. However, the 'lostness' is purely temporal/social. There is no sense of eternal weight or the gravity of being lost before God.
quotes: In the short run, we would bet on the power structure... In the long run... they vanished and never left a track in the sand.
the entire power structure... tremble, because they know down deep that this is the good wave of the future.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Incorporate the seriousness of the 'narrow way' as a matter of ultimate destination, not just social progress or historical legacy.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'telos', but He functions more as a model for 'transformative work' or a 'word of life' than as the Savior who is God. The focus remains on the 'Jesus movement' and 'disciplines' rather than the person and work of Christ.
quotes: It is this love to which Jesus calls his disciples.
That is what Jesus did with his life, and then he would have his disciples do that same transformative work...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Shift the focus from 'following Jesus' (discipleship) to the 'One Lord' who accomplishes for us what we cannot do for ourselves.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At roughly 1450 words, the sermon would take approximately 14-15 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition of the specific text to meet the minimum 20-minute threshold required for substantive proclamation.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily because it lacks a specific biblical focus, opting instead for a thematic address on discipleship. It functions more as a motivational speech for a ministerial installation than a 'recreation' of the Word of God. The 'misery' of man is reduced to social anxiety, and 'redemption' is largely replaced by human 'disciplines' and 'transformative work'.
strengths: Concrete connection to the local congregational occasion (installation of a minister).
Effective use of political context in the analysis of Luke 3:1-2 to challenge the status quo.
weaknesses: Lack of focus on a single pericope; too many texts used as proof-texts for a theme.
Duration is too short (approx. 14 minutes) to achieve theological depth.
Theological shift toward human action (discipleship) at the expense of Christ's unique work (grace).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This text is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker's definition. It is a thematic speech about the gospel and church life, lacking the specific textual grounding and the necessary length to be an actualization of the Word of God.
